SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Without doubt the most significant thing to emerge from the events of the last 24 hours is not what the Royal Commission on Australia's Security and Intelligence Agencies said and what has been said in the aftermath about Mr Combe, not what the Royal Commission has had to say about the honourable member for Port Adelaide (Mr Young) and not what it has had to say about the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation or Mr Ivanov; the most important thing to emerge over the last 24 hours is what this whole event has revealed about the character and the conduct of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke ). This report, the events and the response of the Prime Minister and of the Government have revealed beyond doubt that this country is now led by a very vulnerable Prime Minister whose authority on matters of duty as distinct from matters of loyalty and mateship is very weak indeed. This demonstrates that faced with a choice between mateship and duty the Prime Minister will forsake duty and prefer mateship.

SPEECH.PARA: Not one of us in this House would denigrate the Prime Minister's affection for his friends. Not one of us in this House would deny to the Prime Minister that very admirable Australian quality of mateship and fraternity towards one's friends. But one of the prices one pays for high political office, and supremely in the case of the Prime Ministership of this country, is that when it comes to the crunch duty to one's country and to one's Government is more important than loyalty and mateship. That is the overwhelming failure and weakness of this Prime Minister and this Government. That ultimately is what will condemn him not only in this Parliament but also in the eyes of the Australian people.

This event and the circumstances of the last 24 hours have demonstrated that this country is led by a craven populist who puts loyalty, mateship and popularity in the short term above long term considerations. He has done that with the Government of the country as far as the economy is concerned. He is waxing fat in a political sense through the fortunate circumstances of Australia 's economy at present. He is caring not about the problems that his wages policy is storing up for the future of the Australian economy. He cares not about the erosion of our competitive position. Equally with the circumstances of this event, instead of having the courage to take on his Caucus and saying 'Look comrades, there is no way in the face of the finding of this Royal Commission report that we can possibly have Mick Young back' what does he do? He cuts and he runs. One can only wonder whether, in fact, some kind of deal was not done between the left wing and the Prime Minister on this issue. One can only wonder- -

TALK.START.PARA: —No deal.

—Of course, the honourable member says there were no deals but one can only wonder whether, in fact, there were. Everybody around this building knows, as the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) pointed out yesterday, that the Prime Minister has been backgrounding for weeks that the honourable member for Port Adelaide would be out in the cold. He has been going around this place saying to the journalists: 'Forget about it; Mick has had it. Mick is on the way out. We are not going to bring him back'. But when it comes to the crunch the Prime Minister is not prepared to confront the Caucus. He is not prepared to tell the Party that he leads that its duty lies in rejecting the honourable member for Port Adelaide and not returning him to the Ministry.

SPEECH.PARA: But the political crime of the honourable member for Port Adelaide-it is a political crime-runs far deeper than the finding of the Royal Commissioner. It goes far deeper than the fact that the Royal Commissioner found that the honourable member had made an unauthorised disclosure and that that disclosure was improper. More importantly than that-this is a political arena; this is a parliamentary arena-the former Special Minister of State lied to this Parliament . That is the great political crime the honourable member for Port Adelaide has committed. Not only did the former Special Minister of State lie to the Parliament but also, indeed, did the Minister for Finance (Mr Dawkins) and the Treasurer (Mr Keating). The Treasurer will no doubt wax on about telephone calls and unspecified memoranda. Honourable members opposite can all get very worked up about that. They now have a trifecta of ministerial liars sitting in the ranks of the Hawke Government. The presence of the former Special Minister of State, the Treasurer and the Minister for Finance is sanctioned, condoned and encouraged by the Prime Minister of Australia who, when it really comes to the crunch, will always put loyalty, political survival and political popularity above everything else. He has failed the most essential test of any great political leader and that is that when the crunch really comes--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order.
—It is starting to hurt a bit, is it?
—The Deputy Leader of the Opposition referred to the Ministers as liars. I think that is unparliamentary and should be withdrawn.

—Order! There is some substance in the point of order, but the term has been used on both sides of the House. I remind honourable members that although this is a debate on a censure motion unparliamentary language is not allowed to be used.
—If the Government wants the language moderated, Mr Speaker, I will do so.
—I would prefer it to be moderated.

—Not only was the former Special Minister of State found guilty of an unauthorised and improper disclosure; not only did he mislead the Parliament but also if one carefully reads the evidence one sees that he is placed in the invidious position of being told by the Royal Commissioner that, to put it very mildly and euphemistically, he was guilty of a great amount of selective amnesia . On page 185 of the Royal Commissioner's report the Royal Commissioner states:

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Walsh's account of his conversation with Mr Young contains three matters additional to those contained in Mr Young's version of the same conversation . . .

He goes on to list what those three matters were. Elsewhere in the Royal Commissioner's report one finds evidence that, to put it mildly once again, the honourable member for Port Adelaide was less than fulsome in the disclosures he made to the Royal Commission. On three counts one has the finding of an unauthorised and improper disclosure, the misleading of the Parliament and also this conflict between the evidence of Walsh and the honourable member for Port Adelaide. Probably the greatest illustration of the vulnerability of the Prime Minister's position on this issue is the fact that he made a 17 1/2 minute speech, was granted an extension of time and mentioned everybody in the Parliament, past and present, except the former Special Minister of State. He spends all his time talking about other people but does not mention the former Special Minister of State. The Prime Minister has demonstrated during this debate and by his response to this report that his standards of propriety, his standards of political leadership and his view of parliamentary and ministerial responsibility are infinitely inferior to those of former Labor Leader, Gough Whitlam. At least Whitlam had the courage to dismiss Connor when Connor was found guilty of misleading the Parliament in 1975. At least the then Prime Minister, Whitlam, had the courage to fight it out in the Caucus and to say: ' Look, you cannot maintain in your Government somebody who has been guilty of misleading the Parliament'. Whitlam-from a position of political vulnerability compared with the present Prime Minister's very different position in the present situation-was willing to confront his Caucus, to show leadership and to demonstrate a standard of propriety that this present Prime Minister is simply unwilling to do.

Once again the Prime Minister of this country is indulging in and sanctioning double standards on the part of his Ministers. He was prepared to tolerate the double standards of the Minister for Finance (Mr Dawkins), the great character assassin of this Parliament and the person who more than anybody else under the cover of parliamentary privilege last year was prepared to malign and traduce the reputations of honest and respectable Australian people. He was prepared to tolerate it then. He was prepared to remain silent then. He asks us to have some sympathy for the honourable member for Port Adelaide in his family predicament. Of course, all of us do. We might well have asked him to speak out against the despicable attack made by the the Leader of the Opposition on the former Attorney-General when he blamed the former Attorney-General's heart attack on that gentleman's handling of his ministerial portfolio. As far as I am concerned , the Prime Minister's totally artificial outrage would be a little more convincing had he dissociated himself from what the then Leader of the Opposition had been prepared to say on that occasion.

Whilst we naturally extend personal condolences to the honourable member for Port Adelaide for any family loss, let us not be diverted from what this Prime Minister is really about today. This Prime Minister is in a predicament. He knows what his duty is. He knows darn well that the former Special Minister of State should not go back into the Ministry. He knows well that he is breaching proper standards of parliamentary and ministerial propriety. But he cannot do anything about it. The reason he cannot do anything about it is that the honourable member for Port Adelaide has the numbers in the Caucus, and he is such a craven populist that he is not willing to take his Caucus on. He had the audacity in this Parliament to invite the Australian people to believe that the former Government's standards of ministerial propriety were inferior to those of the present Government. Any objective political scientist would concede that the standards of the former Government and of the former Prime Minister of this country, who displayed twice the strength that this Prime Minister displayed on this occasion in dealing with ministerial propriety, were infinitely superior to those being displayed by the Prime Minister in the present circumstances.

The double standards of this Government and of this Prime Minister do not stop when it comes to the way in which he totally ignores the fact that the present Treasurer misled the Parliament last week about the response of the Economic Planning Advisory Council to some economic projection. The double standards of this Prime Minister do not stop there. In the tabling statement that he made to the Parliament yesterday he correctly recorded many of the findings of the Royal Commission. Perhaps to the disappointment and chagrin of some members of the left wing of his Party, the Royal Commissioner said that the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation did not do a bad job in the affair. We on this side of the House are very pleased that the opportunity has not been given to those in the Labor Party who would wish to do so to make ASIO a scapegoat in this whole affair. But the Prime Minister, lighting upon the fact that there were some circumstances in which ASIO fell short of an absolute standard of perfection, thumped the table and said: 'We are going to demand a high standard of performance from ASIO'. Apparently it is all right to demand high standards of performance from the Public Service. It is all right to demand high standards of performance from ASIO. It is all right to demand high standards of performance from Mr Combe. But for heaven's sake, do not demand high standards of performance from the honourable member for Port Adelaide because, after all, he is one of their mates and he has been in the Labor Party for 30 years. The poor, old, selectively amnesic honourable member for Port Adelaide has been in the Labor Party for 30 years, has worked very hard and, of course, deserves a break! He is a very inexperienced politician! He was only the campaign director for the Labor Party in 1972. He only knows every trick in the book, beyond the capacity of most other people. Yet we are invited to accept this and to pass it over.

This debate and the events of the last 24 hours have demonstrated that, when it really comes to the crunch, this Prime Minister is not prepared to do his duty. This Prime Minister does not have the strength that many people in the Australian community believed he had. This Prime Minister will also fail the test on future occasions when he has to choose between popularity and duty. That , I put to the House, is an absolutely fatal flaw for any Prime Minister of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was somewhat amused to hear talk about lying coming from the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), the champion liar of 1983.
—Order! The Minister will withdraw that statement.

—I withdraw it, Mr Speaker. He is the man who, in the same spirit of mateship with Malcolm Fraser, stopped him telling the truth about the $9.6 billion Budget deficit we were facing in the middle of the election campaign. If one wants to talk about lies, there is the great lie to the Australian people in the critical week of an election campaign when judgments were being made about economic competence. Yet the Deputy Leader of the Opposition talks about the honourable member for Port Adelaide (Mr Young) lying to the Parliament when he and his leader lied to the nation in the critical week of an election campaign.

SPEECH.PARA: We also heard him, of all people, talk about what a royal commission found. The Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union found against his administration for five years when he was Treasurer. This is the man who nearly destroyed the corporate taxation system of Australia. This is the man who cowardly-I emphasise the word 'cowardly'-hung behind the Commissioner of Taxation suggesting that the incompetence in the management of the taxation system was all his doing. In fact when the Commissioner of Taxation published a telephone book of letters we finally found out who the liar was-the honourable member for Bennelong, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition. We will not be lectured by him about who liars are.

I find this a joke. We are sitting here being told about honour and principle by people in the last Cabinet whom one could not knock out of the Fraser Ministry with a Cruise missile. It would not have mattered what a royal commission or a judge said; they sat it out like India rubber men bobbing up and down as the punches came. Just consider the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) talking about principle! He discovered all of a sudden that his estate was worth $600,000 more than he thought. He did not know where the $600,000 came from, and nobody alerted him to it until a couple of old ladies decided to take him to court over it. It was finally decided that this great man of principle who lectures us about principle, after he was dragged through the courts, had to give the money back. So, he should not lecture us about principle. The Leader of the National Party (Mr Anthony) consorted with criminals. He went to Long Bay Gaol to see Harry Miller. I do not think the Prime Minister consorts with criminals. I have not seen this Prime Minister consort with convicted criminals as has the Leader of the National Party. Let us deal with all those former Ministers. Mr Nixon remained in government even after the findings of a royal commission. We will not be lectured by honourable members opposite about principle or honour. They have no principles and they have no honour and they never had. We are not in the slightest way impressed by any of the remarks that they have made.

Let me just make this point: Where is the public interest in all this matter? The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) started his attack on the Prime Minister by saying that the Prime Minister had no genuine concern for the public and no understanding of leadership. Those were the two charges he made. Does any honourable member believe that the charge that the Prime Minister has no genuine concern for the public can be sustained? What was the public interest in all this matter? The public interest was whether Ivanov was a security risk to this country. That was the public interest. What have we found from all the mealy- mouthed attacks by honourable members opposite about that matter? The Government was cleared absolutely for its competence and propriety in handling the issue of Mr Ivanov. The Government was cleared on the matter of the Opposition's mealy- mouthed attacks on the Prime Minister for supposedly tipping off mates. But the Leader of the Opposition did not have the decency to make an apology when an expressed finding of the Royal Commission on Australia's Security and Intelligence Agencies cleared the Prime Minister of any wrong doing whatsoever; in fact it endorsed his action and said that it was with complete authority that he got in touch with Mr Farmer in that matter.

Who let the security concerns overcome them? Certainly not the Leader of the Opposition who breached a commitment to this Government by allowing George here to get up and ask a question in which he named David Combe in Parliament. That is where David Combe's name came in. If there has been any destruction of Combe it resides with the right honourable member for New England, the Leader of the Opposition, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition and the honourable member for Warringah (Mr MacKellar) who asked a series of questions and first named Mr Combe in Parliament. When we talk about the threats to national security the principal issue is Ivanov and all the affairs surrounding Ivanov. The Government was given a clean bill of health on this matter.

As far as Mick Young is concerned we have not said for a moment that what he did was excusable. We have not said that for a moment. We have said that there was no damage to national security, that he paid his price and that, therefore, he was entitled to come back into the Cabinet. We never ever saw this sort of action from the former Government. It always resiled from any responsibility to have any inquiry. It crept around corners and attacked judges as the former Prime Minister, Mr Fraser, attacked the report of the Woodward Royal Commission into the Australian Meat Industry. We turned all these matters over to a royal commission and we then stood up in the Parliament and said that we believed that Mr Young had paid his price and he was entitled to come back. We, like every other government, will let the public make its judgment at the poll. We will let the public make a judgment about the Prime Minister's view on this matter. I am sure that the public's judgment will be that the Government was justified in letting Mr Young return to the Government. I am sure that the public will support the Prime Minister's judgment in this respect as well. But the Leader of the Opposition talked about principles and returning to Cabinet.

TALK.START.PARA: —What happened in Queensland a few weeks ago?
—Order! I warn the honourable member for Maranoa.

—The Leader of the Opposition talked about principles and returning to the Ministry. Let me just recount some of the things he said upon his resignation. In his letter of resignation to the former Prime Minister he said:

SPEECH.PARA: I hereby tender my resignation from your Cabinet. This decision is irrevocable.

I believe you have cast aside the stability and sense of direction of the Government. Indeed you have a dangerous reluctance to consult Cabinet and an obstinate determination to get your own way. As stated this decision is irrevocable . . .

He says twice in the one letter: 'This decision is irrevocable'. But what do we find? Out he goes on 15 April 1981 and back he comes crawling, slinking into the Cabinet of Malcolm Fraser on 11 October 1982. When he realised that there was really no point in sitting up on the back benches, playing cards every day with Barry Simon and generally amusing himself like the clown he is, without any attention to any more serious obligations that he had in this Parliament, he finally thought that when that policy was not working he would get his backside back into a ministerial car and get the salary again. So back he came. Good old Andrew. Come on Daisy. Back he came, back into Malcolm Fraser's Cabinet. Was Malcolm Fraser any different? Was he less obstinate about getting his own way? Did he have different policy about the way in which he treated his Cabinet? He treated honourable members opposite for what they are-a bunch of mugs. I do not blame him.

As far as honourable members opposite are concerned, the former Prime Minister realised that when you nurse a mug he will die in your arms. The Leader of the Opposition died in Malcolm Fraser's arms on every occasion. The former Prime Minister treated the Leader of the Opposition with the contempt that he deserves . It must gall Malcolm Fraser to see that a fop such as the present Leader of the Opposition replaced him as Leader of the Liberal Party. When we look at the cowardly attack which the Leader of the Opposition made on the former Prime Minister-not over Kampuchea, not when this matter came up-because his selective indignation was well and truly covered up and he was not going to be indignant about losing his place when there was criticism of Pol Pot and the murderous regime of Pol Pot was being exposed, we see that he did not resign then. He resigned months later because the former Prime Minister said something nasty about Barry Simon. That is why he resigned. How dare the former Prime Minister say something nasty about Barry Simon. He could not cop that. He just had to resign over that. This is the great man of principle. Does he really think that we are going to listen to him? Does he think we are going to stand up and say: ' Oh yes, Andrew, you have said all that. We have to tell Mick Young that he cannot come back, that the Royal Commission has damned us.' The Royal Commision would wipe the floor with honourable members opposite time in and time out. When we look at the report of the Costigan Royal Commission we see that Costigan changed the debate in this country about taxation. If the Deputy Leader of the Opposition was an honourable man he would not be in Parliament, let alone sitting in this chamber lecturing us about principle and everything else. So much for the leadership of the Opposition. So much for the Leader of the Opposition, his deputy, the Leader of the National Party and his deputy and their roles in all these affairs.

The Prime Minister referred to an even more important matter. He referred to the matter of Mr Philip Agee. This is something which must be seen in its true perspective in order to be understood. What happened on this occasion was that the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock) who was then Foreign Minister-not the Leader of the Opposition with a licence that leaders of the Opposition enjoy -exposed and named five agents of the Central Intelligence Agency operating in Australia while he was Foreign Minister. He named them but it was a gaff. One of the headlines in the newspapers reads: 'Peacock denies CIA slip-up'. Another headline reads: 'Peacock says Government knew of CIA men then denies it'.

If one has to be honest and if the Leader of the Opposition was honest could he suggest that Mr Young's behaviour was in any way more deleterious to national security than the things which he had to say as Foreign Minister? Of course he could not. But what happened then was that he said that he did not intend to damage national security. If Mr Young says that he did not intend to damage national security that is to be overlooked but when the Leader of the Opposition says that he did not intend to do it he is supposed to be exonerated because he is a Liberal. He is part of the bunyip aristocracy, a remnant of the failed upper class, one of the crowd who reside in Melbourne and govern Australia. He is supposed to be let off while the rest of us are supposed to pay the penalty. We will not pay the penalty because the former Government set the standards about whether Ministers should resign over certain things. In this respect what we find is a total breakdown of integrity on the part of the Leader of the Opposition in an instance very similar to this one where he exonerated himself and where he now asks of Mr Young his continuing absence from the Ministry, whereas he slunk back into every Ministry into which he could get himself.

The other charge that the Leader of the Opposition made was that the Prime Minister had a pathological pursuit of David Combe. But everything, and I emphasise the word 'everything', in the Royal Commission report rebuts that charge. The report says that the Government did everything appropriate to protect David Combe's name. When reference is made to the meeting between the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) and David Combe the express question is asked in the recommendations: Did the Government honour the undertakings given to Combe at that briefing after he was named in the House by Mr Sinclair? The positive answer to that question is: Yes, the Government did honour those obligations and did nothing to upset or dishonour those obligations. In fact, the only breach of agreement was Mr Combe's own statements in breach of the arrangement he made with the Government.

The Government did everything to protect Combe's name while Opposition members took the sleazy, political path. They do not understand what leadership is all about. Leadership is about leading on issues when one has to overcome tawdry political opportunism. The reason the Leader of the Opposition could not overcome tawdry political opportunism is that he is no leader. He is a weak man who is run by the National Party of Australia. The Leader of the Opposition was leading on this issue, he was running this issue, until the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) and wheat bag, the Leader of the National Party, decided to get in and run the issue for him. That is when the Leader of the Opposition got pushed to one side and that is when George decided to name David Combe in Parliament. That is a fact. The Leader of the Opposition is not a leader's bootlace. He talks about leadership. Leadership is doing the right thing and the hard thing. The Leader of the Opposition does not know what that is about, he has no idea. He exploited this issue for his own advantage, he exploited it up hill and down dale.

The Royal Commission overwhelmingly and absolutely endorses what the Government did. It supports the Government in every respect on its handling of the affair. But the Leader of the Opposition could not overcome cheap political opportunism. He did not even have the decency to apologise when there was an express finding against the charges he made against the Prime Minister. On all counts, the Opposition's basic charge that the Prime Minister has no concern for the public interest is false and is a lie. The claim that he has no leadership is false and a lie, and we reject it absolutely.
